job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The students. But as a faculty or staff member, that is a natural thing to have an affinity for.
cons: Poorly led institution that is bleeding financially. The MN nice attitude and passive-aggressive behavior has unfortunately placed so many in positions where it further hurts the institution. I was there long enough to see the turnover of deans and other leaders. All of them brining in new ideas but the core infrastructure is not sound enough to implement changes. Additionally, and probably most importantly, the faculty and staff that are the face of the institution are treated poorly. They become forced to take on so much and become deflated as resources are stripped away.

job_title: Production Manager in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Love working with the students. Their passion, dedication, and commitment to learning and developing skills for the professional world is fantastic.
cons: Terrible pay, management continues to cut positions but saddles you with more and more work. The Faculty (Professors) create an environment where staff are looked down upon and treated poorly - they frequently do not include staff in communication channels which then creates lapses in productivity. The University's leadership has no clear vision for how to adapt to the changing educational landscape, and continue to defund educational programming.

job_title: Operations Coordinator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Close knit departments, flexibility within team
cons: Smaller student population and it can be very slow work wise. Also, the pay is not great and not as much new employment opportunities within the organization.

job_title: Cashier in Saint Paul, MN
pros: can do homework at shift
cons: hard to get shifts covered

job_title: Student Organizations Coordinator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Close knit student orgs, clear communication
cons: Hours can shift based on student schedules, which is pretty expected

job_title: Central Service Desk Worker in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Flexible hours, decent pay, nice bosses, room for growth. Opens a lot of doors in IT.

job_title: Data Steward in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Great staff, student, and faculty culture
Shifting to new and better ideas in a lot of areas
Treated like a professional in a serious, but not overly stressful environment. Despite still navigating many issues Hamline does a better job than many of taking D&I issues seriously.
cons: Has been continuously reducing the benefits package over the last decade. Pay has also remained mostly stagnant. Hamline chooses to balance the budget off the backs of employees in most years. Only 2 weeks vacation starting.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Excellent colleagues, inspiring students, good work atmosphere
cons: Wear lots of hats, high turnover

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Can do homework, get paid, and have a chill environment.

job_title: Public Safety Officer in Saint Paul, MN
pros: steady work, many of the students are very great to work with

job_title: Director in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Hamline is a warm and welcoming place with terrific people who are deeply committed to educational equity.
cons: Like many small liberal arts colleges, enrollment is down right now and base salaries are low.

review_title: The Highest Density of Race Relations.
job_title: Graduate Student in Saint Paul, MN
pros: A belief in the outdoors and outdoor classrooms.
cons: Like most Methodists, a backward minded, low technology institution founded on the basis of racial profiling, anti colored people sentiments, and a money-making scandal with no respect for academic achievements.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The benefits are pretty good and reasonable in cost - if you're a single person.  The vacation and sick leave accruals are generous.  They give 5% of your annual salary into your retirement account, and will match up to another 2.5%.
cons: Although Hamline claims to be "all inclusive" and welcoming of all viewpoints, the reality is if you are a Christian or a conservative under no circumstances should you make that known - you will be shunned and/or bullied.  For example, several years ago a faculty member discovered a fellow faculty member had voted for a Republican candidate and she said to that person, "How could you do that to me? I can't be friends with you anymore."  Sadly, this is all too common here.  Their HR department is a complete disaster.  They have A LOT of turnover university-wide.  No salary increases for years on end.  Many staff are extremely overworked and highly stressed.

review_title: Relaxing work environment, but no room to grow.
job_title: IT Systems Integrator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Very few deadlines, comfortable self-paced daily work and projects, friendly co-workers and understanding of work/life balance. Also decent pay/stress ratio, great place to work if you just want to do your job, stay under the radar and live your own life.
cons: Positions are quite confined. You are encouraged to only do the work requested of your position and there is no room to grow, transfer, or be promoted as each position is similarly filled and there is little turn over. As such there isn't much industry expertise so you won't be learning a lot of new skills. Also, benefits have been trimmed quite a bit during 2012-2013.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Worked directly with extremely passionate, committed and creative people. The higher education environment offers many perks, including better benefits than many organizations; tuition breaks; health and wellness resources and promotions; a close-knit community
cons: Mismanagement by upper administration led to mass layoffs, irresponsible spending, turnover, and low morale campus wide. Management does not listen to or support employees; human resources is ineffective.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Supportive colleagues, family friendly, wonderful student body- diverse, eager, dedicated, good-natured. 

The Twin Cities are a great place to live and work.
cons:
Lower pay than other regional universities. 

That is really the biggest issue on campus that hurts morale. New President is looking to change that.

review_title: This was a good place to work because of the coworkers.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I had a good boss and the coworkers were great to work with.  Working a students everyday was also a unique opportunity.
cons: The lack of upper management involvement and recognition from the director levels at a relatively small operation made this job frustrating at times.

review_title: Hamline is a nice place to work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Hamline's new president, Dr. Faynese Miller, has injected a sense of collegiality. Hamline is very mission driven with a strong emphasis on civic engagement and social justice.
cons: The salaries tend to be lower than they are at other similar institutions--and without a sense that an increase is in the offing. There's a "Hamline Way" of doing things that's tough to get, but the way itself is a cool thing.

job_title: Server in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Easy job, nice for students to work and go to school at the same time. It's a nice job to do until you get a job in your field.
cons: Low pay, the people that work there are strange at best but nice enough. Because Hamline partners with Aramark, alot of the people you work with are full time workers which is nice; but htey can be kind of strange at times.

review_title: Pros and Cons of working at Hamline University
job_title: Director in Roseville, MN
pros: The staff, faculty, and students at Hamline are collegial and motivated. I enjoyed my time at Hamline immensely. My job was eliminated in 2012 during a period of financial instability at the institution.
cons: The administration did not seem interested in ensuring that the institution's infrastructure was adequate given student needs. The institution also has a history of financial instability.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Hardworking group of dedicated employees with sincere interest in students education and college experience. Your opinion matters and there are many opportunities for university wide involvement.
cons: There are limited avenues for career advancement.  Private colleges have suffered in recent years with the downturn of the economy and money is always tight.

review_title: Great experience and the best best people.
